review_title: An unpleasant experience with some positives
pros:
At MO, managers make a show of superficially doing the right things. They will be noisy about diversity and inclusion, supportive during the pandemic etc. 
Salaries are fair
Offices provide a pleasant working environment
A lot of nice, talented people work there.
There is a genuine focus on delivering a good service for customers.
cons:
The monopoly nature of the business has a lot of perverse effects on the culture. Notably, there is a layer of management who are drawing huge 6 figure salaries far beyond what they could get elsewhere. This means there is a static group of managers where no one leaves, In the time I was there not a single head of function departed the company. There is an unofficial a system of patronage, so those who manage up assiduously, drink the coolaid and replicate the "strong culture" tend to be the ones that are rewarded. As a consequence there is a layer of ambitious managers and team leaders with little regard for those lower on the totem pole than them. They will happily take credit for the work of subordinates but make sure blame finds its way to the bottom of the tree.
The lack of financial pressure in the business means incompetent managers can buy there way out of trouble, by bringing in expensive consultants and contractors to get them out of a jam. 
It is only after moving to a new employer where managers are genuinely supportive and invested in your success, that you appreciate how corrosive this kind of place can be on your well-being.

job_title: Customer Experience Specialist in Bristol, England
pros: Salary is good for a call centre role Nice clean bright office with a cafe that serves free barista coffee Recruitment team and Net training team who you deal with initially are super friendly and welcoming however you then don’t interact with them day to day Good office/home balance which is flexible and days can be changed if needed Internal vacancies seem to crop up a lot with opportunity to work elsewhere, however I imagine lots of people apply for these roles
cons: Recruitment process and initial training lures you into a false narrative of what the job involves. All seems extremely positive at the beginning however as soon as you’re on your team taking calls it quickly turns into a less pleasant/more stressful experience. My first con is as a customer experience specialist you’re dealing with complaints/customers complaining practically all day, however have very little scope or the tools to help which is frustrating for the customer and the staff member. You’re criticised and marked down on your call gradings for phoning third parties and going the extra mile to help, as this affects your stats, even though you’re told in training to use your own empowerment and do what’s best for the customer. You feel like you can’t win. If the customer wants to escalate their complaint there are then a couple of further teams you can raise them to which is a confusing process in itself, but the customer will have to wait a further day for a call back which frustrates them even more. I’ve never worked in ‘customer service’ where the ‘customer service advisor’ can’t just resolve it all on the first call- surely that’s the whole point of a customer service team? It feels unproductive passing the customer from pillar to post. Secondly the company preaches about how it’s supportive of mental health, however it seems to be that the job is actually the thing having a negative affect on people’s mental health. You’re run into the ground taking calls back to back and they’re even now potentially removing the natural wrap time so you’re immediately put back into a call. The managers don’t realise how mentally draining the calls can be and sometimes you need a minute to breathe and de-stress inbetween customers. The managers and coaches seem to try and morph you into some type of Motability Robot, sounding the same as everyone else. My manager compared me to someone who had worked there for years when I had worked there for one month saying ‘you should aim to be like ****’ which is an unhealthy approach and made me felt like I was being forced to sound differently on the phone, as I wanted to do what was expected of me to pass my probation. I’ve been pulled up on accidentally logging in 1 minute late or accidentally calling a customer by their first name, numerous other petty things but ultimately I’m only human. You’re made to feel like a child not treated as an adult. Not to mention someone I know of who had mental health related absence during probation so she was let go of. To summarise, MO doesn’t practice what it preaches in terms of mental health. There are a few other annoyances of the role, during probation being expected to listen into calls in your own time after work and unpaid. When you finish at 19:00 and on a Saturday not actually being able to log out until everyone is out of the queue and it’s closed off and a manager emails everyone (which can take up to 5 minutes every day and you don’t get the time back, but it all adds up). They’re quick to pull you up about coming back from your lunch 1 minute late but happily expect you to stay 3 minutes every late/Saturday after work until they close the phone lines. Having no time or phone code to read through emails during the working day, so you can miss important information but can’t do anything about that because you’re always expected to be taking calls.

review_title: Doesn't practice what it preaches, would not recommend
job_title: Customer Experience Specialist in Bristol, England
pros: *Good Pay for role type (Excellent yearly Bonuses if your face fits) *Good benefits package *Free Coffee Shop *Reduced Priced Canteen *Excellent initial training - with emphasis on Cognitive disability education and awareness * Lots of updates/communications or training regarding changes * Most Staff are friendly and welcoming
cons: * Lack of diversity within the contact centre in management/coaching roles. * The job is sold to you as a ‘one stop shop’ customer service role where you have your own empowerment to make decisions and help your customer. However, the role at present is moreso that of a complaints handler or a switchboard operator. You more often than not cannot solve the customers query at source because resources are not there to do so. This means some of the customers, who have been used to a very responsive quick solve to issues, become very quickly frustrated. These issues are prevalent due to changes in the worldwide car market and are out of Motability’s control. However, this means that staff need more support and means to help. Having empowerment can only go so far when you’re telling every customer ‘its out of our hands’ and ‘we can’t do anything here to help you with your query at present’. This is affecting many members of staff mental and physical wellbeing. * Call grading can be very confusing for some members of staff. You’re advised to use your empowerment, don’t be scripted, be yourself, use resources around you and keep a solid call structure and you’ll be fine. However, it’s not quite that simple and more often than not if you do everything asked to get a good grading, you’ve then gone above the call time targets. It’s a very precise recipe and a rhythm you have to find yourself but not an easy skill to grasp. The frustrating thing is…. If you get a sub par quality call… you’re not given direct feedback to work on regarding that, nor are you able to listen back to that call like you can other calls. There is not enough transparency to help those struggling and coaching sessions alone cannot help with this. This is a vast cause of anxiety with new starters. * 'Discretional' nature of management powers /behaviours give for a vast amount of inconsistency between supporting members of staff with welfare concerns. Some managers are incredibly empathetic and go above and beyond. Others, do not. This culture makes it feel difficult at times to approach your own manager if you have an issue. I know I personally did not feel comfortable doing so unless necessary. * Probation is a taboo word. No one will ever truly discuss it with you and its is a vast cause of anxiety for new starters as its such an ‘face fits’ system. It should not be treated in this nature. Sadly there is a large turn around of staff. Site security have openly commented on this. * Unfair probation system. To pass probation you are advised you must meet Key performance indicator targets (%) for call quality, statistics, absence etc and a ‘business decision’ is made. However, this is again discretional and if your face fits/your manager likes you you are passed. They advise that the whole picture is taken into consideration. However, this really does not seem to be the case. I know of many with sub par performance who were passed probation and others who were not. I know of those with excellent quality but slightly higher absence who have been failed and other passed. I equally know of someone with a low performance and a higher absence who was passed. To make matters even more inconsistent, there is sometimes just a call with your manager to advise of a pass or sometimes a meeting with a HR rep. Sometimes your review meeting is brought forward and sometimes it’s not. * Male recruitment manager for the role is lovely and personable during recruitment. However, once you have completed training comes across very unfriendly. He has personally ignored me communicating with him on two occasions. I know of other colleagues who’ve faced the same behaviour which is very out of place as the department is that of friendly personable people who all greet one another. * Lack of support to staff with Cognitive Disabilities. As a company they give their employees access to wellness apps, counselling helpline, an initial wellness passport, mental health allies and medical cover including an online digital GP. This is all amazing and can be really helpful for some. So, at its core there is a want to support staff and keep them well. However, from the perspective of an employee there is a lack of understanding from Contact centre management in how to support those within the workplace with conditions. Occupational Health referrals are often completed too late/not at all and there aren’t enough discussions regarding reasonable adjustment that a disabled employee is entitled to. There are of course some managers that are really supportive and lovely, but others that really don’t care less and view helping those with welfare concerns as ‘hand holding’ or reasons for them to have extra work to do. Sadly, I faced the latter who I felt really did not always listen or communicate well with me. I did not feel comfortable speaking with them or raising any concerns til it was too late and I needed to take some absence. I know of other colleagues who felt the same way and/or had less support than myself both in terms of adjustment or paid sickness. I see this as a huge con as Motability consider themselves a disability inclusive employer, but sadly don’t offer consistent help to their staff. As the job can be very draining at times this is something that sadly I saw affect many members of staff but they didn’t feel able to say at source with their managers out of fear it would come back against them in probation reviews, which sadly, does seems to be the case. * 6 day working week once per month. That week you only get 1 day off which is very draining. There is a half weekday rota’d in to this. However, you still work the weeks full hours to get that half day. This is not enough time to a member of staff to rest.

pros:
Having experienced it myself and read all these reviews before and after starting my job PROBATION IS TOUGH but there is a reason for this, Motability pays very well but they want the right type of person. They keep people on who genuinely care about the customer and go beyond just taking a call. If you want to help people and are naturally kind and empathetic you will pass probation. If you fake the empathy to get through the calls you wont make probation as it will show. 

- Amazing training at start, and through out. 
- Monthly coaching sessions, EVERY MONTH, to work on what you think you need to improve, this is on YOU to put the effort in and say what you want to improve on.

LOTS OF THESE REVIEWS ARE NEGATIVE, these are mainly from the people that cant preform the to standard they have agreed to preform at. I have had a period where my performance dropped and i was not doing well i was given lots of support. From monthly coaching to weekly coaching and lots of feedback on calls. Celebrating good ones and discussing how to improve when I got bad ones. 

IF YOU WILL WORK HARD AND CARE ABOUT THE JOB YOU DO AND WANT TO HELP EVERYONE FROM THE CUTE AND THE NICE TO THE THE CALLERS THAT ARE GRUMPY OR MEAN TO YOU ECT. You will go far in Mo but if you only want to be nice and helpful on days you feel like it you WONT do well here. I was told 3 times in probation if i don't improve i wont pass, but i worked harder and i passed. It is a great company to work for as long as you dont expect everything to be handed to you with no real effort on your part.

There is progression routes, but you have to work for it, and you may not get it the first time, but you just need to persevere and try again. review_title: Pay is great - everything else not so much.
job_title: Contact Centre Advisor in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: I’ll start by saying that the pay is excellent for a call centre role - it’s probably the best out there. However, don’t be fooled by this. It’s not an easy job and there’s a number of reasons why.
cons:
Firstly, I’d like to start on training. Training was excellent, 5 weeks of really in-depth training and our trainer, Lee was awesome. Couldn’t fault him. 5 weeks felt like a good amount of time to learn about the job and the tasks we would need to undertake. 

But then comes probation. I don’t really know where to start. It really felt like you were thrown in the deep end. The most frustrating part is the ‘coaching’ that was provided. The coaches are designed to support and help you when all it ever made me feel was frustrated, angry and stupid. Be prepared for your coach to ask YOU questions, not the other way around. They will deflect any questions you ask them by asking YOU instead - “what do you think? How do you think it went? What could you have done?” My coach made me feel small, inadequate and there were a couple of times I cried because the type of questions asked were so vague I had to keep asking her to narrow the topic down , feeling like an idiot in doing so. Another girl in my team had this happen to her too. Also, there’s not much point in explaining yourself to your coach because they won’t like you standing up for yourself - so basically you’ve got to suck it up. 

Be prepared to be told that ‘you are responsible for your own training’. I’d take this with a pinch of salt. You could try, but if your face and personality doesn’t fit the Motability mould then you’re gonna have a difficult time getting through. 

The last few weeks of my probation, I was told I’d be getting a lot of contact time between my coach and manager. That didn’t happen. As days went on, it was obvious they had already made a decision on my probation. Contact became less and less frequent. 

They will only make you listen to your poor calls, average calls and never your very good or excellent. They won’t even tell you what you did in those calls that made it very good. They will however, happily dissect what you did wrong in a poor call. 

Be prepared to do a lot of work outside of office hours. If you really want to try and pass, your coach and managers will fully expect you to invest your own time to work on your performance. 

It’s stats based. If you’re 0.2% under your target it’s not good enough and they will make you well aware of this. I got told I didn’t pass probation and was then told that my manager would be escorting me out of the building, in front of my team and fellow colleagues. I cannot tell you how humiliating this was, to pack my things, handover my laptop and lanyard for everyone to see. Because I knew this was coming, I took it fairly well but I cant imagine how I would have taken this had I been upset.

cons: No progression, money is too low for work expected. If your manager is problematic you kind of have to take it until you cnt take it anymore and leave. Management are very sneaky.

review_title: The best job I've ever had
job_title: Contact Centre Advisor in Bristol, England
pros:
Amazing recruitment experience - both in terms of the activities undertaken and the amazing recruitment team that put you at ease and keep you informed throughout the process. Sach and Leon have a relentlessly engaging energy and keep checking in on you once you are 'live' on the phones to make sure you are all settled in. They truly go above and beyond to make you feel welcome. 

Training and communications team work tirelessly to run a robust and detailed training scheme. This has to be one of the most comprehensive development programmes I have ever seen. Not only do they equip you with all the tools to do the job, they then provide a supportive 'academy style' environment to get you warmed up on the phone. You have the opportunity to listen into experienced advisors and there's always someone to call on should you have a question. 

MO has adapted very well to pandemic challenges by removing PC's and providing everyone with laptops, providing flexible working opportunities and a fully hybrid method of working. Colleagues can work safe in the knowledge that their preferences and COVID concerns are addressed and true thought has gone into making sure everyone can enjoy working safely. Some may have reservations about working and learning over Zoom, but MO's support networks mean this process works seamlessly,

Management are approachable and welcome you like you've worked there for years. You are supported with regular coaching, reviews and catch up's to ensure you can achieve your potential. Feedback is direct, honest and without any mixed messages. People are genuinely supportive and want to help you to thrive. The work environment is fun and there are plenty of extra-curricular networking groups to get stuck into.

On site catering, facilities and parking are second to none. It makes all the difference knowing that you can come into the office of a morning and just get on with it without having to worry about where lunch is coming from, or where to park. It really is an effortless employment experience - and at the end of it all you can come home and put your feet up without worries of a poor work-life balance.

Yes, some people may say the calls are intense, or it's busy all the time, or expectations are high... and all of the above is true. And so it should be. MO is a market leading company which requires market leading staff. So if you can't stand the heat - you definitely need to get out of the kitchen! So if you're looking for a challenge to sink your teeth into; this is the role for you!
cons: The company has adapted their tech well to the needs of hybrid working; but there are some gaps. However, MO are on top of it and I've got every faith that the technology will continue to evolve with faster / more robust laptops and further customer innovations.

job_title: Customer Contact Advisor in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: The company has a good wage for a contact centre advisor, good health benefits as well as scheme memberships. Some management are fantastic such as Chris and Nat, who I cannot fault in terms of compassion and care ethic.
cons: Our group were put through a four stage interview. I could not fault Leon or sach who were amazing upbeat and offered lots of support and encouragement. We went into training with Lee who was also great although we felt this was rushed through no fault of his. After training we attended academy where we were put straight onto phones which as a group we felt we were not ready for. Our group was 10 people. Thereafter we were put into our teams. The team culture is very different where it feels one side of the room is friendly encouraging and helpful, the other side not so much. Very unsupportive and somewhat cult like. It very much felt on the other side if the face fits which is a let down to the good side. Management are varied and again if the office was sliced in half it was mean to say there was a good side and a bad side. I have to say team Dacia and Chris who manages the team is incredible. Very friendly down to earth and welcoming. Unfortunately this is not the case for every team. I also touch upon facilities. You are shown round by someone who appears very friendly however once you are out academy she will not even acknowledge you are there which is disappointing given your initial first impression. Out with the office the canteen staff and coffee takeaway staff are brilliant. If only this was the case in the later side of the office. You are made to feel like you have a false pretence to upkeep within your probation, where numerous people have actively said through conversation they feel anxious coming into the office as they are the new people and passing probation is notoriously hard, which again makes people feel uneasy. After having a good observation in the office and spending time there it feels very much in the Edinburgh office if the face fits within different teams which goes against the company values. I feel management should be looked at, although I for one cannot fault again Chris and Nat who are both exceptional people and actually care. I cannot say the same for the others where I have heard somewhat negative input. I really do hope as a company that Leon can address these issues and hopefully put a means to an end to this where it comes to new starts as this could be a fantastic company to work for if management in Edinburgh were managed properly.

The size of the business is such that you can get your arms around it and build relationships with all areas of the company; which helps foster a lovely working environment.

review_title: Great place to work and develop your career
pros:
In my opinion Motability Operations is a great place to work. The company offer a good benefits package and market leading pension contributions, as well as bench-marking salaries competitively to the wider market.

As an organisation it is highly customer focused with a culture of going above and beyond to provide first rate customer service.  I have always felt the company is well managed from the top down.

There are development opportunities available but I would stress that it is very much a company where you get out what you put in. You can't expect to be handed progression on a silver platter and you do have to fit with the company culture to move upwards.
cons:
Relatively flat structure means that progression is sometimes slow. This does however ensure that as a general rule the right people move up within the company.  

Other issues that come to light through annual staff engagement surveys are taken seriously and dealt with where possible - this year we have seen systems improvements, parking improvements and better management communication.

pros: Best offices I've ever worked in love the soft seating areas for breaks, lots of fun in the department, reward and recognition for a job well done and plenty of opportunities for career development with the support to help you get there. You have to work hard but you get a great pay and benefits package in return and there are also secondments available which I've found a great way to try a job out and learn about other areas of the company before taking the plunge and moving jobs permanently.
cons:
It's hard to avoid all the sweet treats on offer but fruit is usually available too if you can tap into your will power!

Traffic is a nightmare in the mornings because of road closures (metro bus) and UWE but leaving a bit early and having a bacon butty in the canteen helps alleviate this!

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Bristol, England
pros: Salary and benefits but remember if it looks too good to be true it probably is
cons:
Employees seem micro managed at every level with the feeling that you're being constantly watched and judged... ( See 'Coaches' below) 
People working here were seen behaving like 'Stepford wives'... The whole process was quite deeply unnerving. 
Worst of all, the managers not upfront about the 6 month probation process. This is a brutal pass or fail which they seem to conveniently fudge over.  However, one scenario group exercise, which was judged as part of the recruitment, involved 'sacking' someone who was having some personal issues along with mixed reviews of their performance. There was no option given to extend their probation so the only option was sacking them. If this is how new employees are judged during probation then that's a bullet well and truly dodged!
Employees micro managed at every moment of the day amd performance managed  by given a strike during probation for being a few minutes late to work or being a couple of minutes late back off their break.
There are people termed 'Coaches' who monitor your every working minute. They wield all the power and seem to be looking to fault rather than coach or mentor.
I was strongly left with the feeling that this is the kind of place where if your face doesn't fit or you ask too many difficult questions or have any personality at all you're gone! 
One Coach I witnessed was really unfriendly and had obviously got out of bed on the wrong side that day... 
Applicants are made to jump through many hoops to get up to this stage. MO are still advertising weeks after the assessment day... So obviously despite offering what appears to be a good salary, potential recruits are either being too harshly assessed or MO have set impossibly high expectations.  
The average length of time anyone stays at MO is just over 4 years which speaks for itself.
 Motabiltly Ops  are recruiting  for 40 positions however I firmly believe that the true number of posts expected to remain after month 6 will be much less and that a large proportion of those taken on will be got rid of during the probation process or 'managed out' leaving around 20 or fewer in my opinion.
This was by far the most unnerving aasessement process I have experienced. 
The worst thing is that on the surface everyone seems really 'nicey nicey' and the benefits seem amazing. 
Sadly, as with many things if it looks too good to be true it probably is!
